Do you like the interiors

Bombay cuisine is a vibrant mix of seven culinary influences ? Parsi, Malwani, Goan-Portuguese, Anglo-Indian, Bohri, Gujarati, and Maharashtrian with each adding its own spice to the city?s food story.

With this thought in mind Master Chef Ajay Chopra has opened his latest restaurant in Gurgaon called So Bombae. 

This is such a refreshing concept and will also be the first one in town to serve Bohri cuisine. Yesterday, I checked out this restaurant with Ashish Bhasin , Sanghamitra Dutta Bhasin and Aradhana Soni and were totally blown away by a few dishes like pomfret filled with prawns, seekh kebab reminiscent of bun kebab, chaat served on Japanese shisho leaves, the Anglo Indian pork belly and so much more. 

We were so full with the starters that we didn't venture into the main course at all. Will plan another visit soon. Hopefully by then So Bombae would also get its liquor license.

If my expression looks almost similar in all videos, it is because of the exemplary meal I had yesterday at Swan.

I have been to many pop-ups this year, even by Michelin-starred chefs, but last night?s at Swan by Chef Takashi Namekata (Dubai?s TakaHika) and Chef Krishna was hands-down my favourite.

Every course was a hit: white fish with shaved black truffle, pulled lamb tart, Chef Krishna?s leche de tigre mackerel, and lightly seared fatty tuna that made me shamelessly ask for seconds. Then my all-time weakness, yuzu miso black cod, followed by grilled scallop in herbed butter, eel, and lamb shank in puff pastry. Sushi with hand-carried salmon, akami, and chutoro closed the savoury courses, and truffle ice cream sealed the night.

All of this, at ?7000 all-inclusive, for ingredients mostly flown in fresh. No wonder the place was packed for both seatings. If you can snag a table tonight, do not miss it. Some meals are truly unforgettable.

As I board an Air India flight today, my heart feels heavy. Over 300 lives were lost in the tragic AI171 incident. A number far too great, a tragedy far too preventable.

While investigations will eventually reveal who is to blame, the signs have been clear for years. Broken seats, dripping air conditioners, nonfunctional entertainment systems, indifferent crew, constant delays. The fall of the once regal Maharaja is heartbreaking. What was once a symbol of Indian warmth and pride now feels like it is being run by a profit-hungry system where people no longer matter.

Flying in India is anything but cheap. A two-hour round trip in Europe or Southeast Asia with a no-frills airline might cost around eight thousand rupees. Here, we often end up paying twenty thousand and still get less than basic service. And we are told fuel surcharge justifies the cost? Really? Can fuel surcharge alone increase ticket prices three times over? In a country where manpower is affordable and supports everything from maintenance to baggage handling and airport operations, this explanation simply does not hold.

The DGCA must stop acting like a bystander. If poor maintenance turns out to be a cause, should the regulator not share the blame? Oversight means nothing if it only shows up after lives are lost. This is the same DGCA that fails to ensure compensation for delays, cancellations, baggage mishandling, overpriced tickets or even food and stay during disruptions. Do they lack the powers or are they conveniently turning away in exchange for favours?

So many lives are gone. Let this not become another tragedy lost in the news cycle. Let this be the moment we demand change, accountability and decisive action before more families are shattered in the skies.

Mother to my two beautiful daughters, the queen of our little world, and the only person who can make life as entertaining as it is unpredictable. What makes good food great is the quality of ingredients and the passion with which it is cooked. Indian Accent is one such example that has become India's number 1 restaurant by giving people the nostalgia with a modern day presentation. 

The 15th year celebration menu is fantastic. I went back in time to the Manor hotel where the Indian Accent started. Anyone who can make hygienic golgappa with the same chatkara as the Street food vendor has already nailed it. Carrot cumin soup was so good that we asked for a repeat.

The dishes are many but since they come in small portions, one can easily enjoy them. There are a few surprise dishes too that the chef sends on his own. Like the ribs with mango relish is just mind blowing good. So was the kanyakumari crab.

Paired with the beautiful wines, this is one meal one should certainly go to experience what good Indian food is all about.

Art has its language and it speaks louder than words. MasterChef Fu Lei, the one who opened The China Kitchen at Hyatt Delhi has joined JW Marriott Pune and is currently doing a Pop Up at Eest, The Westin Gurgaon till 31st August.

I along with a friend wanted to check out his Sichuan inspired bold flavours and visited yesterday for lunch for a beautiful meal.

We started with the beaten prawn pumpkin soup drizzled with sesame oil. The prawns were filled with something, though I couldn't make out what was inside due to communication issue. Perhaps this was the only mild dish in what all we ate.

Large chunky mala prawns spoke of the quality ingredients. Though not as numbing as it may sound, we totally loved them. I wouldn't have ordered string beans unless my friend insisted but it was so good that we wiped the entire plate clean.

No one goes wrong in ordering Lobster and we did that in XO sweet pepper. The best dish of the day was the squid, calamari, sea bass and prawns in spicy sauce served with jasmine fried rice that has fried shrimp and truffles in the shaving.

Only miss in this event is the dessert. They have their regular desserts but nothing from the visiting chef's kitty.
